componenttext: Really, I can't speculate at this time as to any potential timing for liability recognition. Investigations have really just begun, and so we're really just focused on cooperating with CAL FIRE as they investigate the sources of these fires.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Byrd with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Byrd with Morgan Stanley.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just -- I know inverse condemnation is a very popular topic. I just wanted to make sure that I understood your perspective to it. So I understand your perspective is that if inverse condemnation did apply to utilities, then utility should be a
componenttext: I wanted to just -- I know inverse condemnation is a very popular topic. I just wanted to make sure that I understood your perspective to it. So I understand your perspective is that if inverse condemnation did apply to utilities, then utility should be able to recover those costs. And if I've -- I may have gotten that position wrong, but regarding your position, what is the path to be taken to attempt to clarify how, if at all, inverse condemnation should apply to utilities? Is that through the CPUC? Is that through a court process? Or is that too early to say?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, Stephen, this is Geisha. Let me go head and get started. So we don't believe that inverse condemnation is inappropriate doctrine and we certainly don't believe that it is appropriately applied to investor on utilities. Whether and how inverse condem
componenttext: Well, Stephen, this is Geisha. Let me go head and get started. So we don't believe that inverse condemnation is inappropriate doctrine and we certainly don't believe that it is appropriately applied to investor on utilities. Whether and how inverse condemnation is decided to be applied is really up to, I believe, a court. We would challenge its application if, in fact, it were to be determined that our facilities were among the causes of these fires. We would challenge it to the extent that -- and again, if we were to not be successful and having inverse condemnation not be applied, then we would expect that the CPUC would take action as a consistent really with the underlying purpose of the doctrine, which is, of course, that our cost over and above insurance coverage should be shared by all customers.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Understood. And then, I guess, just looking forward at a high level, there've been a number of statements within the state around looking more broadly to address the impacts from climate change. And obviously, wildfires are one element o
componenttext: That makes sense. Understood. And then, I guess, just looking forward at a high level, there've been a number of statements within the state around looking more broadly to address the impacts from climate change. And obviously, wildfires are one element of that. Is there a potential here for a broader process within the state, really a forward-looking process where you reassess what is the fire risk, what are the other risk and climate change? And how do we as an industry better address that proactively as sort of refine standards, beef up this mitigation measures, whatever it might be? Is there sort of possibility for something more forward-looking to come out of these wildfires?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I appreciate that question. As I think on it, as I look at this, in my mind, there's no question that we're seeing the impact of climate change. And you're seeing what's happening in the Caribbean, with this horrible hurricanes in Florida, in Texas
componenttext: Well, I appreciate that question. As I think on it, as I look at this, in my mind, there's no question that we're seeing the impact of climate change. And you're seeing what's happening in the Caribbean, with this horrible hurricanes in Florida, in Texas with the incredible flooding and now here with this truly extraordinary event that we experienced in Northern California. So as we take a step back and do everything we can to combat climate change, we also need to be taking actions to look at how do we make our infrastructure? How do we make society overall as resilient to the effects of climate change if possible. And we think clearly, there's a role for the state to play in that, and we would welcome an opportunity to participate in a broader, more comprehensive discussion about the actions that all of us, all of us need to take to be able to better withstand the ravages of climate change.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Understood. And Geisha, is your sense that there is a willingness within the state to try to engage in that broader dialogue?
componenttext: Understood. And Geisha, is your sense that there is a willingness within the state to try to engage in that broader dialogue?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, when I think about California and our leadership position on all things climate change, I think it's a natural progression. I certainly don't want to speak for anyone in the government, but I welcome the opportunity to be at the table and have an ab
componenttext: Well, when I think about California and our leadership position on all things climate change, I think it's a natural progression. I certainly don't want to speak for anyone in the government, but I welcome the opportunity to be at the table and have an ability to talk about it from our point of view. Again, we've been such a leader for years, for decades really and looking at what we can do to really improve the quality of life for our communities. Reduce the impact of climate change that I think, again, it's only -- it's a really natural progression to start looking at adaptation as well as resilient strategies.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Building on that -- this is Nick, that we've actually already begun the process of working with different elements of the communities. We've awarded several grants to help communities begin to understand the impacts of climate change. and what we can do f
componenttext: Building on that -- this is Nick, that we've actually already begun the process of working with different elements of the communities. We've awarded several grants to help communities begin to understand the impacts of climate change. and what we can do from a resiliency standpoint. And also, internally, for planning the long-term future of our electric and gas networks. We've begun to really take a hard look at the long-term impacts of things like higher winds, higher sea levels, more extensive rains, so that we can build more resiliency into our asset structure.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful color. Just one last point on just tax deductibility of fire expenses and damages, whatever those might be. I wonder if we could just get a quick refresher on how to think about the tax deductibility of cost that ultimately are borne b
componenttext: That's very helpful color. Just one last point on just tax deductibility of fire expenses and damages, whatever those might be. I wonder if we could just get a quick refresher on how to think about the tax deductibility of cost that ultimately are borne by shareholders. How should we think about the ability to secure tax deductibility for those costs?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stephen, this is Jason. We'd expect to be able to [indiscernible] third-party claims if we were to be found liable for those. So those would be deductible for tax purposes. The only thing that, in our view, that would not be tax deductible would be f
componenttext: Yes, Stephen, this is Jason. We'd expect to be able to [indiscernible] third-party claims if we were to be found liable for those. So those would be deductible for tax purposes. The only thing that, in our view, that would not be tax deductible would be fines or penalties coming out of any investigation.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Fleishman with of Wolfe Research.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So just -- I don't know if you guys got to see the TURN letter from yesterday, but just at a high level, your point on inverse condemnation and spreading the cost seems to make sense. On the other hand, there's the kind of traditional prudency in all thos
componenttext: So just -- I don't know if you guys got to see the TURN letter from yesterday, but just at a high level, your point on inverse condemnation and spreading the cost seems to make sense. On the other hand, there's the kind of traditional prudency in all those things at the commission. Just so how do you kind of ties those 2 together and argue against customers having to pay for the cost of this?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's John Simon. I'm the General Counsel here. Inverse is, as Geisha mentioned, a strict liability concept. Negligence is a completely different construct. And inverse really excludes the consideration of negligence. In other words, the premise of
componenttext: Steve, it's John Simon. I'm the General Counsel here. Inverse is, as Geisha mentioned, a strict liability concept. Negligence is a completely different construct. And inverse really excludes the consideration of negligence. In other words, the premise of inverse is that the utility pays the property damages and attorney's fees without any showing that it's at fault. And in turn, the utility spreads the cost across all the customers and recovers those costs through rates. So as I understand the TURN argument is sort of apples and oranges to where we are with inverse. So we see it differently.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just tying into that, this seems to be getting back and forth addressed through ex parte or letters in the San Diego wildfire case. Do you get any sense that this could move into a kind of a broader venue of -- because it's such a big precedent-
componenttext: Okay. And just tying into that, this seems to be getting back and forth addressed through ex parte or letters in the San Diego wildfire case. Do you get any sense that this could move into a kind of a broader venue of -- because it's such a big precedent-setting decision-making here. Is there any sense of maybe this -- instead of just deciding there, it gets broaden out into a different type of proceeding?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Steve. I mean, clearly, this issue of liability is such a public policy. It's a significant California issue. And there's no question that the decision in the San Diego Gas & Electric case will be very telling. And so not sure what
componenttext: That's a good question, Steve. I mean, clearly, this issue of liability is such a public policy. It's a significant California issue. And there's no question that the decision in the San Diego Gas & Electric case will be very telling. And so not sure what the CPUC is thinking about at this point. We do know that they've delayed the taking action on it. I think that they're trying to be thoughtful and deliberate and understanding the ramifications of whatever decision that they ultimately end up making. But this issue of liability, again, in California, a state that has a history of extreme weather, extreme wildfires, to that case, is one that has to be dealt affirmatively in the future. So we welcome an opportunity to be able to discuss it, and again, talk about constructive solutions that will be in the benefit of both the state and its many customers.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one just technical question, Jason, on the GT&S 2019 case. You mentioned $900 million to $1 billion of capital spend. Is that -- can you just clarify, is that incremental to what is -- I mean, right now, you're using flat in 2019 as your ba
componenttext: Okay. And then one just technical question, Jason, on the GT&S 2019 case. You mentioned $900 million to $1 billion of capital spend. Is that -- can you just clarify, is that incremental to what is -- I mean, right now, you're using flat in 2019 as your base case. So is the $900 million to $1 billion kind of incremental to that flat?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, it essentially reflects -- our guidance reflects the $900 million that we're spending this year, so the -- for context purposes for 2019, we're providing a range of $900 million to $1 billion, which is on one end flat with our consistent spending. On
componenttext: No, it essentially reflects -- our guidance reflects the $900 million that we're spending this year, so the -- for context purposes for 2019, we're providing a range of $900 million to $1 billion, which is on one end flat with our consistent spending. On the upper end, it could be as much as $100 million increase from where we are today.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's kind of -- it kind of suggest that, that kind of level of spending will continue most likely through, assuming it's approved through this next plan?
componenttext: Okay. So it's kind of -- it kind of suggest that, that kind of level of spending will continue most likely through, assuming it's approved through this next plan?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: That's correct, yes.
componenttext: That's correct, yes.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta with Citigroup.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sorry to beat the dead horse, but I just want to -- on the inverse condemnation point. Just wanted to clarify, if you win your argument, right, so either you are not found to pay even though -- the cause or you're allowed to recover it from customers, eit
componenttext: Sorry to beat the dead horse, but I just want to -- on the inverse condemnation point. Just wanted to clarify, if you win your argument, right, so either you are not found to pay even though -- the cause or you're allowed to recover it from customers, either way it's effectively you're not liable from a shareholder perspective, at least, there's no cost that the shareholder is bearing for this except in the case of gross negligence. If gross negligence is found, then there are penalties, which, obviously, will flow to the shareholder. Is that a fair way to thinking about it?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's -- CAL FIRE is doing their investigation. It's early, as Geisha mentioned. I don't think it's productive for us to speculate on some of the theories in your questions. So I think it's just too soon to talk about sort of these concepts right now.
componenttext: It's -- CAL FIRE is doing their investigation. It's early, as Geisha mentioned. I don't think it's productive for us to speculate on some of the theories in your questions. So I think it's just too soon to talk about sort of these concepts right now.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'll keep it more broad and then you touch on how you feel comfortable, but what I'm trying to understand is if you win the argument on inverse condemnation, in what scenario do you see the shareholder actually bearing any costs related to the fi
componenttext: I guess, I'll keep it more broad and then you touch on how you feel comfortable, but what I'm trying to understand is if you win the argument on inverse condemnation, in what scenario do you see the shareholder actually bearing any costs related to the fire?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I mean, I think you've jumped ahead and assumed that we have liability. So that's why we're uncomfortable talking about really what's in essence a hypothetical situation here. Inverse condemnation is very clear about its strict liabili
componenttext: Well, first of all, I mean, I think you've jumped ahead and assumed that we have liability. So that's why we're uncomfortable talking about really what's in essence a hypothetical situation here. Inverse condemnation is very clear about its strict liability, but also providing the commensurate cost recovery from all the customers that have benefited, if you will, from the services. So it's a question for the juries at the end of the day to determine what the company will be liable for versus shareholders or anyone else for that matter. But it is so very, very early in this whole process to be able to provide you any kind of confidence one way or the other.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got you. Fair enough. I totally understand. Is there, at this point, any internal studies being done to figure out what the maintenance at the levels that you were expected to do? Any results of that internal review, separate, obviously, from all the revi
componenttext: Got you. Fair enough. I totally understand. Is there, at this point, any internal studies being done to figure out what the maintenance at the levels that you were expected to do? Any results of that internal review, separate, obviously, from all the reviews that CAL FIRE and others may be doing?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we are doing extensive fact-finding, given the lawsuits that have been presented before us, and so we are gathering data.
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we are doing extensive fact-finding, given the lawsuits that have been presented before us, and so we are gathering data.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. Okay. And moving on to the tax reform. And I know that this is clearly different from everything else that's going on. But tax reform obviously is coming or at least attempting to come in. Any color on how you think that impacts you guys? Any
componenttext: Fair enough. Okay. And moving on to the tax reform. And I know that this is clearly different from everything else that's going on. But tax reform obviously is coming or at least attempting to come in. Any color on how you think that impacts you guys? Any changes in terms of what that would mean for your plan going forward?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're generally well positioned when you look at all of the various considerations in the tax reform. So we find that we are in a good place overall. But I mean -- Jason, anything you want to add to that?
componenttext: I mean, we're generally well positioned when you look at all of the various considerations in the tax reform. So we find that we are in a good place overall. But I mean -- Jason, anything you want to add to that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, obviously, it's still -- we're still very early in this process. But as we disclosed on the fourth quarter earnings call earlier this year, we think we're, as Geisha mentioned, very well positioned. And then the recent discussions have includ
componenttext: Yes. I mean, obviously, it's still -- we're still very early in this process. But as we disclosed on the fourth quarter earnings call earlier this year, we think we're, as Geisha mentioned, very well positioned. And then the recent discussions have included sort of a phase down of the corporate tax rate. We see that as beneficial to our customers in terms of refunding through the excess amount of taxes that we've collected in the past. And so for us, that would allow us to create sort of build capacity for incremental capital expenditures in our system, which we think would -- and continue to improve the safety and reliability of our gas and electric systems.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: And that refund that you mentioned, Jason, that you still expect to go over a long period of time as a credit to customer bills effectively?
componenttext: And that refund that you mentioned, Jason, that you still expect to go over a long period of time as a credit to customer bills effectively?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Details are going to matter on this one, but I think it's a reasonable assumption to assume that, that would refund back to customers over, essentially, the book life of the assets.
componenttext: Absolutely. Details are going to matter on this one, but I think it's a reasonable assumption to assume that, that would refund back to customers over, essentially, the book life of the assets.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can we just go back to what you said about the Butte fire costs? You said the estimate of the total potential liability is now in excess of your insurance policy. My understanding from prior conversations with you is that, however, you also had access pot
componenttext: Can we just go back to what you said about the Butte fire costs? You said the estimate of the total potential liability is now in excess of your insurance policy. My understanding from prior conversations with you is that, however, you also had access potentially to the insurance coverage of your vendors. You talked about having gotten some of that. So are these costs above the limits of your policy potentially shareholder exposures? Or are you still confident that you have other avenues of recovery through still working with insurance agencies of your vendors and other venues that you will be able to fully recover these costs?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So sort of actually we've recorded insurance receivables up to the full policy limit of our insurance of $922 million. We've collected a little bit more than $50 million to date from our contractors' insurers to the $1.1 billion accrual for third-party cl
componenttext: So sort of actually we've recorded insurance receivables up to the full policy limit of our insurance of $922 million. We've collected a little bit more than $50 million to date from our contractors' insurers to the $1.1 billion accrual for third-party claims exceeds that amount. Consistent with the conversation that we've been having on the doctrine of inverse condemnation, we would expect to seek recovery for those costs from customers and have filed to do so.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, but is there also potential for a reduction in that amount from further recoveries from other insurance companies or no?
componenttext: Okay, but is there also potential for a reduction in that amount from further recoveries from other insurance companies or no?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: We will continue to seek recovery of incremental costs from third-party insurance. But I'm not in a position to provide details on either one there. Their insurance levels are to sort of the nature of those negotiations.
componenttext: We will continue to seek recovery of incremental costs from third-party insurance. But I'm not in a position to provide details on either one there. Their insurance levels are to sort of the nature of those negotiations.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Turnure with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher Turnure with JP Morgan.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on the last question on contractor insurance and maybe apply it to the current wildfire situation. Do you also not have information there on size? Do you -- I guess, contractors or other utility companies have an allowance to char
componenttext: I just want to follow up on the last question on contractor insurance and maybe apply it to the current wildfire situation. Do you also not have information there on size? Do you -- I guess, contractors or other utility companies have an allowance to charge their customers for the insurance premiums? And how can we get a sense of any kind of covers there, if at all?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think I understand your question. I'll try to answer it as I interpret it. We have recovery for our liability insurance cost through our general rate case process. There isn't a separate direct recovery for contractors' insurance. Generally, our contrac
componenttext: I think I understand your question. I'll try to answer it as I interpret it. We have recovery for our liability insurance cost through our general rate case process. There isn't a separate direct recovery for contractors' insurance. Generally, our contractors procure insurance sort of an ordinary course of business. We do not have, as I mentioned, direct subsidization of those costs. And just as for the Butte fire, we're not in a position to talk about the level of insurance those contractors maintain.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then going back to one of the earlier questions or several of the earlier questions. I wanted to just make sure that we were on the same page with your legal strategy. Let's say that on, I guess, next week's decision on the SDG&E fi
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then going back to one of the earlier questions or several of the earlier questions. I wanted to just make sure that we were on the same page with your legal strategy. Let's say that on, I guess, next week's decision on the SDG&E fire. Let's say that it does not go in the favor of SDG&E and the CPUC kind of makes its position known. Is there any change in specific legal strategy that you can take as you begin the third-party challenges for those claims for the Northern California wildfires?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Geisha. I just don't think it's constructive at this point to be speculating about what we might do if this happened or the other thing happened and kind of talk about legal strategies for things that haven't occurred yet. So I just rather not com
componenttext: This is Geisha. I just don't think it's constructive at this point to be speculating about what we might do if this happened or the other thing happened and kind of talk about legal strategies for things that haven't occurred yet. So I just rather not comment on that.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: A process one, and I know this is hard. But in general or historically, how long does it take for CAL FIRE to, a, do its investigation; b, put out reports? And is there any precedent for where it's not just one incident, but it's multiple incidents that o
componenttext: A process one, and I know this is hard. But in general or historically, how long does it take for CAL FIRE to, a, do its investigation; b, put out reports? And is there any precedent for where it's not just one incident, but it's multiple incidents that occur over the same time before you get that?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So we don't have a tremendous amount of experience with this, but our latest experience, I would say, was the Butte fire case. In that particular case, if you recall, the Butte fire actually occurred in September of 2015, and we received the CAL FIRE repo
componenttext: So we don't have a tremendous amount of experience with this, but our latest experience, I would say, was the Butte fire case. In that particular case, if you recall, the Butte fire actually occurred in September of 2015, and we received the CAL FIRE report in April of the following year. So it took 7 months. And if you think about that fire, while it was a terrible fire and very expensive, it was one fire. In this particular case, you have a series of fires all erupting over a several-day period. And so I think the complexity of this particular investigation is much higher. So having said that, how long will it take? I don't know. When you look at the 2007 wildfires that occurred in Southern California, there are multiple fires. And my understanding is that they issued multiple findings associated with those particular fires. And again, that took some time. So I think we're going to have to be patient. What I've read is the same things that you've read in the press. That they're intent on being thorough, on being accurate and I think that they need the time to be able to get to what actually happened, what caused it, what were the different causes of the various fires. I think it's highly complex.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. And when you look at the few wild fire report put out by CAL FIRE, can you compare that to the CAL FIRE report, which the proposed decision in the San Diego Gas & Electric case kind of relied heavily on. What are the similarities and what are the
componenttext: Got it. And when you look at the few wild fire report put out by CAL FIRE, can you compare that to the CAL FIRE report, which the proposed decision in the San Diego Gas & Electric case kind of relied heavily on. What are the similarities and what are the biggest differences between those 2 reports?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't comment on that. I've obviously read cover to cover the Butte fire report, but I'm not an expert on what the San Diego Gas & Electric report looks like, so I can't give you that comparison, the compare and contrast sort of answer that I think
componenttext: Yes, I can't comment on that. I've obviously read cover to cover the Butte fire report, but I'm not an expert on what the San Diego Gas & Electric report looks like, so I can't give you that comparison, the compare and contrast sort of answer that I think you're looking for.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. One last one. How do you -- you've got a lot of uncertainty now about potential costs and about potential insurance recovery, although I think you've disclosed there's kind of a cap of about $800 million of that. How does that impact your br
componenttext: Got it. Okay. One last one. How do you -- you've got a lot of uncertainty now about potential costs and about potential insurance recovery, although I think you've disclosed there's kind of a cap of about $800 million of that. How does that impact your broader financial planning, right? When you're thinking about your capital budget, you're thinking about your dividends, you're thinking about your financing needs. How do you plan around that knowing that for a time period, whether it's 6 months or 2 years, we don't really know. You're going to have a good bit of large dollar potential uncertainty outstanding.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Michael, this is Jason. I think it's just way too early to speculate as to the impact these fires may have, if any, on our financing plans. As I mentioned in my remarks, we reaffirmed the guidance we had issued earlier with the assumption that there's no
componenttext: Michael, this is Jason. I think it's just way too early to speculate as to the impact these fires may have, if any, on our financing plans. As I mentioned in my remarks, we reaffirmed the guidance we had issued earlier with the assumption that there's no additional material impact from the wildfires. We will obviously update you with more comprehensive guidance for 2018 as part of the fourth quarter earnings call. We will take into consideration sort of developments through that period. But right now, I think it's just way too early to speculate as to sort of any impacts on financing, given the fact that cause for these fires has not yet been determined.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Julien Dumoulin-Smith with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017

componenttext: So quick follow-up on Steve's earlier question on CapEx. Just wanted to follow up. I know there was some discussion earlier in the year around $700 million related to the NTSB CapEx potentially. Where do we stand in terms of reflecting that into your expectations, both currently and prospectively in the forecast?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand your question. What NTSB capital?

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017

componenttext: We've seen a reduction in capacity of the insurance markets here in California over the last several years. In California, there's been a number of notable full policy losses in the state of California. In addition, the State of California does have its unusual inverse condemnation doctrine. And as a result, what we've seen is a decrease of available insurance for liability.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017

I guess we've seen sort of end reports that have come out for some of your peers that they sort of track vegetation that's within certain distances from the lines, and they basically make their decisions on what to do based on sort of updates.

headline: PG&E Corporation, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: This is Nick again. Thank you for the question. So as Geisha mentioned, we have a very aggressive vegetation management program across our 70,000-mile -- square mile territory. We manage about 123 million trees that are near and adjacent to our facilities
componenttext: This is Nick again. Thank you for the question. So as Geisha mentioned, we have a very aggressive vegetation management program across our 70,000-mile -- square mile territory. We manage about 123 million trees that are near and adjacent to our facilities. And over the last 2 years, we've doubled the amount that we've invested in veg management. That includes line clearing to remove parts of trees that are adjacent to our facilities as well as removal of dead and dying trees. So the program involves year-round effort to identify these dead and dying trees through inspection processes where we use foot and aerial patrols; we use LiDAR, which is light, detecting and ranging technology, to identify the trees that needs to be worked. We inspect all of our overhead lines every year, and we do second patrols in high fire danger areas at least twice a year. In some areas, we do as often as 4x a year. So it's a very aggressive program. There are specific requirements around line clearing, and it depends upon the voltage of the lines. And it can range up to a feet to as much a sort of 18 inches away from the facility. So there are all sorts of different requirements, depending upon where the facilities are located and the voltage of the facilities.
